results.title: The Last game
results.brief_description: An interactive CD-ROM following a ‘pick-a-path’ approach to a soccer player’s last match. A range of outcomes are generated in reaction to key elememts of a typical football game - penalty kick, injury, extra time. The CD-ROM attempts to describe the possible emotions of the player as he experiences the last game of his career.

results.title: Writers' block
results.brief_description: Writer’s block was developed as a character-driven interactive that gives the user the opportunity to view characters involved in the creative process of writing; including having trouble with muses and getting distracted by too many coffee breaks. The CDROM also contains practical information for would be authors ranging from getting started as a writer through to organising a poetry reading.

results.title: Lit's treasurehunt
results.brief_description:
Lit’s Treasurehunt is a multimedia game for children between the ages of 4 - 7. The main character, Lit, is stranded on an island. A pirate named One-eye asks Lit to help him recover his lost treasure. To do so, Lit has to explore the island and solve a series of tasks.

Lit’s Treasurehunt won the student multimedia catagorey of the Designation Awards, 2002.

results.title: Multiple Xposure
results.brief_description:
Multiple Xposure is an interactive journey that explores the human mind through the use of film, dance, photography and soundscape. The CD Rom follows the life of a character named Stanley with Multiple Personality Disorder. As a photographer he is able to express himself through the images and with constant flashback to his abusive childhood affect his daily life immensely.

The idea is based on an individual’s perception when confronted with visual images. Our interpretation differs depending on our culture, personal background, experiences, personality, gender, psychological makeup, knowledge, interests, intentions and expectations. What a photographer captures on film depends on the above factors.

The body movement of dances fascinates the artist therefore he used this medium to provoke the audience’s state of mind and also soundscape was the inspiration of the series of photographic images.

results.title: Roar culture
results.brief_description:
‘Roar culture’ is a successful six month community arts project that was documented on video. The project brought together schools, community groups, artists, people from culturally diverse backgrounds and local government, including over 80 students, 10 storytellers, and 14 artists/mentors. ‘Roar culture’ explores issues of identity concerning ethnic, religious & sexual discrimination, cultural diversity and tolerance.
In doing so, it was critical to the process that there was a space for understanding and insight: a space where the many faces and voices which contribute to Bendigo’s historical and contemporary image and identity, were paid attention.
Stage one: the project’s starting point was the narrative or story. Stories from 10 multicultural & indigenous individuals whose memories ranged from the 1930s through to today, from places and countries which hauntingly navigated us to Bendigo. Each told a different story about living in regional Victoria however the threads of isolation, language difficulties, fragmented families and broader cultural or religious differences provided significant links.
Stage two was a mentor program, which furthered the developed the artistic skills of the students through a variety of cultural & arts mediums. These included workshops exploring Aboriginal dance; Japanese movement and theatre; contemporary and traditional music from a cross section of cultures; photojournalism and visual art mediums.
Stage three included a series of round table discussions and practical workshops uniting the stories of Stage One with the skills development of Stage Two. This enabled scripts & a musical score to be written for the final stage.
Stage four included performance rehearsals & backstage skills development which culminated in an experimental performance through multi-disciplined artforms in the round at The Capital Theatre on July 16 &17 1999.
Participating in this project were students & teachers from Bendigo Senior Secondary College with members of the stage design crew from Girton Grammar School and Catholic College. An original score of music was composed by local musicians and performed by the Bendigo Youth Orchestra. Financial partners were City of Greater Bendigo, Festivals Australia, The Myer Foundation & Victorian Multicultural Commission.
‘Roar culture’ was awarded the 1999 Local Government & the Arts Leadership Award for Best Practice Management of a Cultural Project

Lynda Newton
Project & Artistic Director

results.title: Woomera 2002
results.creator_credit: Anthony Snowden, Tom McKendrick, Laurel Heisman and SKA TV
results.brief_description: During Easter 2002, activists from around Australia converged upon Woomera Detention Centre to protest the federal government’s mandatory detention of refugees. Activists coordinated with the detainees’ protests within the detention centre, resulting in the mass breakout of 50 refugees. Most of the escapees were returned to the detention centre, but 11 detainees achieved freedom. The activists continued to protest the inhumane treatment of refugees in detention throughout the weekend, expressing their solidarity with both the detained refugees and also the people that escaped. This incident led to an increase in global awareness surrounding mandatory detention policies in Australia
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Snowden, Tom McKendrick, Laurel Heisman and SKA TV

results.title: The Olympic flame and the peace fire
results.brief_description:
The year 2000 saw water in the normally dry Lake Eyre. Life flourished there. But nearby, uranium mining was poisoning the land, and sucking millions of litres of artesian water each day. If Sydney was the headquarters for the Olympic Games, the shores of Lake Eyre was the base for a group of peace activists.
In June of that year, two very different journeys commenced. One was the journey of the Olympic Torch and the other was a walk by group of people carrying a sacred fire with them, who wanted to spread the message of peace.
This documentary explores the beginnings of both journeys. It presents the start of the Olympic Torch relay through another perspective and shows what wasn’t seen by a global Olympic audience - a walk by a small group of people from the the shores of Lake Eyre to Sydney to raise awareness about nuclear issues and promote peace.
The decision to do some filming was made in Coober Pedy two days before the Olympic Torch Relay commenced. In an old Subaru station wagon, Melbourne-based Sam de Silva, Michael Lumsdon and ‘Fergus’ travelled to Uluru, Alice Springs and Lake Eyre Peace Camp over a period of 3 days to document the story of the Olympic Flame and the Peace Fire.
An Access News story. Voice over by Alex Kelly.

results.title: Casterton lights up!
results.brief_description:
Casterton is a small rural town roughly half way between Melbourne and Adelaide, in far western Victoria. Like many smaller rural communities, Casterton has a rich agricultural history that claims not only to being the birthplace of the Kelpie but the first permanent inland Victorian settlement.
Due to a loss of both government and local industries during the nineties, Casterton found itself struggling to maintain its population. In April 1995, a public meeting was called to establish a survival plan. Attended by a hundred or so locals, the meeting produced a number of community initiatives including the developmentof a local phenomenon into a public festival.
In the eight years since, the annual Christmas lights festival has grown into the most important event on Casterton’s social calender. Today, two thirds of all homes in Casterton are lit each Christmas with up to 10,000 visitors passing through the town each December to take part in the nightly lights tours run by the local Lions Club
Casterton Lights Up! is an independently produced community documentary project written, directed, produced and funded by Melbourne Based filmmaker Glen Moore. The project was developed with the assistance and keen support of the Casterton community and aims to highlight the importance of community connectedness and spirit to the survival of small rural communities.
